column4: it was hard, but I think I found your actual question.  What ubuntu version?
autoremove /should/ work.  But if it's not, you can just purge apache2.2-common

I have found it as well. Everything is ok. Some of experts here don't know what theyr talking themselves. apt-get remove apache2 doesnt actually remove it, thats a fact and it is documented on the internet. Dunno why some people try to call me fool if I say that I dont agree with them
yeah, apache2.2-common did the trick
ok, glad you solved your issue.
if you want to learn about upstart, you should read the upstart cookbook at: upstart.ubuntu.com/cookbook
also, is this a different system than the one you were purging apache from earlier?  You told me you were on 11.10 a few minutes ago
it was 11.10
and what version are you on now?
there's an upstart job that's responsible for running the sysv scripts (on ubuntu anyway)
ok. Which one is it?
rc
it exists and looks normal, but probably doesnt work
well that's not supposed to happen :)
runlevel:/var/run/utmp: No such file or directory  search tells me that it is an upgrade bug
what's the result of « uname -r »?
there are two issues: 1) that's not an ubuntu kernel and 2) that's not a version of the kernel available on 11.10

the runlevel does return a runlevel; you know this because MonkeyDust answered you earlier.  The reason yours does not work is likely related to the fact that you are using a non-ubuntu kernel.  My advice is to ask for support from the vendor providing you with said kernel
might be true
they aren't broken; that site is actually just complaining about a debian decision to make runlevels 2-5 identical (which is a design decision; they work as intended by the developers)
I think contacting your vendor is what you should do now; we cannot help you further
